title: What can be an example of a valid argument with a false premise and a false Conclusion? - Quora

response.answer_text: If you mean a conditional argument of the form P => Q then any two false statements can be said to have that form even if they are unrelated. You may have heard people say, “IF <premise> THEN I am a monkey’s uncle”. This is sound logic even though the conclusion is necessarily false (unless the premise is found to be actually true). Even statements that are obviously unrelated qualify. For example: “IF Isaac Newton is alive today THEN Hillary Clinton is the current US President”. This might appear to be a ridiculous statement since there is no known connection between Isaac Newton and Hillary Clinton but in a conditional statement, if the premise is false then the conclusion can be true or false so this statement qualifies as a conditional statement. Also, the premise will never be true so we can’t prove that the conditional statement isn’t true meaning that we can’t prove that there is no connection between these two people. Although not required by the rules of logic, some may insist that the conditional statement be demonstrably true even if the premise and the conclusion are always false before we can give it the form P => Q. That is no problem: “IF the moon is made out of cheese THEN the moon is edible”.

I hope you will agree that “If , then .” is a valid argument. (We could make it in more detail by referring to the explicit axioms or theorems that let us make such an inference.) Now substitute in , and , or any other unequal pair., to get a false premise and a false conclusion.
